   World-Wide

doc\n900402-0142..content:
The results, to be released today, confirm what many
scientists and consumers already knew: calcium builds bones.
But this research shows a link between childhood diets and
bone mass.
   Marketers are skeptical, however, that the results will
help the consumer products giant's Citrus Hill brand juices,
which trail in third place in market share behind Minute Maid
and Tropicana.
   "This won't set the world on fire," said Michael Bellas,
president of Beverage Marketing Corp. Added Tom Pirko,
president of Bevmark Inc., a management consulting firm:
"They may be able to make more claims about their juice, but
it's not like they're rediscovering oat bran."
   Besides, P&G launched its calcium-enriched juices three
years ago and it hasn't made a big difference in P&G's share
of the juice market. "People aren't enthralled," Mr. Pirko
said.
   The study, funded by P&G and the National Institutes of
Health, was conducted on 50 sets of identical twins, from
five to 14 years old. Testing twins eliminates genetic
differences and helps control other factors, like environment
and diet.
   Each twin ate a daily diet containing about 900 milligrams
of calcium. One twin also received a 1,000 milligram tablet
of the calcium supplement each day. The preliminary results
show substantial improvements in bone density in the forearm
of the twin receiving the supplement. Precise measures of the
improvement weren't available because the tests will continue
for another year, researchers said.
   The only place this supplement is found is in P&G's Citrus
Hill Plus Calcium juices. To get the same dose, consumers
would have to drink three, six-ounce servings a day.
   Previous research had already indicated that the
supplement is more fully absorbed than calcium carbonate, a
common calcium supplement, said Judy Z. Miller, associate
professor of medicine at Indiana University.
   "Calcium is calcium," she said. "But this supplement makes
more calcium available to the body."
   Others were skeptical of the supplement's impact on
disease, such as osteoporosis, a brittle bone disease that
affects about 20 million people in the U.S. "Children that
get supplemental calcium or a high-calcium diet, regardless
of the source, will end up with denser bones," said James
Simon, a reproductive endocrinologist at Georgetown
University. "Any extrapolation on the risks of osteoporosis
{later in life} is unwarranted."
   P&G officials said they don't have immediate plans to
launch new promotions of the Citrus Hill products or to
introduce new products containing the supplement.
doc\n900402-0142..title:
Calcium Supplement in Some P&G Juices
   Strengthens Children's Bones, Study Says
   ----
   By Alecia Swasy
   Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal

doc\n900402-0113..content:
The report, based on a survey of 75,000 farmers in early
March, is the first indication provided by the government of
the size of these crops. As such, it is eagerly awaited by
agricultural export and commodity industry analysts as a
harbinger of crop price trends for the year.
   The corn planting figure was about what analysts expected.
But the soybean acreage, while down from a year ago, still
exceeded most expectations.
   "The soybean figure is a bit of a surprise," said Conrad
Leslie, futures analyst and founder of Leslie Analytical in
Chicago. He said that based on prices offered by grain
elevators and others after the figures were released Friday
afternoon, soybean futures for November delivery could open
for trading about five cents a bushel lower this morning on
the Chicago Board of Trade.
   On Friday, November soybean futures closed 7.25 cents
higher, at $6.22 a bushel. The planting figures were released
after the close of trading.
   Corn futures for December delivery gained 0.75 cent a
bushel to close at $2.5425 on the Board of Trade.
   While no change is foreseen for corn acreage in Iowa and
Illinois, the largest corn growing states, corn growers are
expected this spring to plant an additional 2.5 million acres
elsewhere, including 300,000 acres in Nebraska, 200,000 acres
in Minnesota and 450,000 in Ohio.
   In a separate report on grain stocks, the Agriculture
Department said corn stockpiles as of March 1 had declined 8%
from a year ago to 4.81 billion bushels, and soybean
stockpiles grew 19% to 1.06 billion bushels. Wheat stockpiles
dropped 23% to 944 million bushels during the period.
   The current inclination to favor corn over soybeans this
spring reflects, among other things, a recent softening in
soybean futures prices as farmers and traders wait to see how
aggressively Brazilian farmers will market their newly
harvested soybean crop, analysts said. If a recent currency
devaluation and other radical economic reforms force them to
be aggressive sellers, the resulting sag in U.S. soybean
prices could impel American farmers to plant more corn at
soybeans' expense.
   "There are no soybeans planted yet," says David Asbridge,
an American Soybean Association economist. "Things could
still change."
   The survey of planting intentions also shows that the
higher target price for corn under the government's
commodity-subsidy program continues to make corn more
attractive than other less-subsidized feed grains.
   Barley acreage is expected to fall 3% from last year to
8.89 million acres, sorghum acreage is expected to fall 9% to
11.5 million acres and oat acreage is expected to fall 9% to
11 million acres. Of that, oat growers are expected to
harvest 6.35 million acres, down 8% from last year, and leave
the remainder as a cover crop.
   The department estimates winter wheat acreage -- planted
last fall for harvest by early this summer -- at 57.2 million
acres, up 4% from the previous year. Winter wheat accounts
for three-fourths of the U.S. harvest. A 4% increase would
more than offset the expected 12% drop in durum wheat
planting and a 4% drop in other spring wheat planting.
   The decreases foreseen for sorghum and spring wheat
acreage this year may be exaggerated, department analysts
cautioned. Many winter wheat farmers replanted their fields
with spring wheat in Washington state and Idaho, and with
sorghum in Kansas, after cold weather killed their emergent
crop of winter wheat. This inflated the acreage figures for
both crops, they said.
   Of all major crops, cotton is expected to show the
greatest expansion -- 17% to 12.4 million acres, which is
slightly more than industry analysts had projected.
   Because of a large cotton surplus last year, the
department required cotton farmers to set aside 25% of their
acreage. The requirement was lowered to 12.5% this year as
strong export demand cut cotton stockpiles in half.
doc\n900402-0113..title:
U.S. Survey of Farmers Sees Plantings
   Of Corn Up by 4%, Soybeans Down 2%
   ----
   By Scott McMurray and Bruce Ingersoll
   Staff Reporters of The Wall Street Journal

doc\n900402-0008..content:
For the evening, I'm playing left wing for the Lords, an
amateur ice-hockey team, not to be confused with the Chicago
street gang. The Lords compete in the advanced-intermediate
level of a nationwide league called Hockey North America.
Participants spend a day a week pretending they can skate and
shoot like Wayne Gretzky and Mario Lemieux.
   Since 1980, the HNA, based in Washington, D.C., has grown
from 100 players to more than 12,000, in 26 cities. The
league attributes its success in some measure to the
continuing national fitness craze. But hockey, with its
furious pace and bump-and-grind action, has a more basic
appeal: "This is not a yuppie sport," says Gary Poteshman,
who sells cutting tools and has played with the Lords for
five years. "When you put on all your equipment and go out on
the ice, you become a totally different person. You're a
warrior."
   Many players also are attracted to the HNA's brand of
play: no fighting or serious checking; that is, no slamming
opponents into the side of the rink. The league enforces the
rules: Each year, the HNA suspends (for from two years to
life) several dozen players because of excessive violence.
   That doesn't mean HNA games are as harmless as a
low-impact Jane Fonda workout. Even with the no-checking
rule, players collide in tussles for the puck. "It's very
physical," says Max Mintzer, a tax specialist for Northern
Trust Co. and HNA's Chicago-area coordinator. "People are
swatting at you. You get elbowed in the head. I've seen a
couple of guys break bones." Since its inception a decade
ago, the league has had two deaths, both from heart attacks.
   At the beginner level, HNA takes any man or woman brave
enough to apply. Some 10% of those who join have never
skated. When I phone the league to ask if I can play in a
game, I am grilled about my experience -- not to determine if
I can hack it, but to make sure I'm not too good. "We don't
want you to go out there and mess up a game by scoring five
goals," a league official tells me. I assure him that that
isn't likely: I'm a potato-shaped newsman who hasn't played
ice hockey since college 14 years ago. The only other thing
the league wants to know is more ominous: Do I have adequate
health- and life-insurance?
   The Lords' roster includes a supermarket manager, an IRS
attorney and a district manager for Baskin-Robbins Ice Cream
Co. The youngest player is 22; the oldest 39.
   Before playing in my first game, I attend two team
practices. During these sessions, our coach, Bill Christy,
puts us through a series of passing, skating and shooting
drills that last about an hour. At first, my biggest obstacle
is getting comfortable with the 25 pounds of hockey gear I
have to wear: elbow pads, shoulder pads, armored gloves, shin
protectors, padded pants and helmet. I figure if hockey
doesn't work out, I can always join the bomb squad. The only
parts of me that are unprotected are the backs of my legs, my
inner arms and my neck.
   I feel like the Michelin Man as I skate clumsily around
the rink. By the second session, a week later, my feet are
covered with Band-Aids, but I'm skating forward and backward
without feeling that I am about to capsize. The coach says
I'm ready for my first real game, which is to be against the
Bandits.
   Before the game -- played at 10:30 on a Tuesday night when
normal people are getting ready for bed -- I set what I think
are some reasonable goals for myself: Try not to fall down
and don't get sent to the penalty box. In general, I'll be
satisfied so long as I don't disgrace myself or get carried
off the ice on a stretcher.
   OK, I'll admit it, I also dream of skating up ice like a
National Hockey League star and blasting the puck past a
terrified goalie. I realize that is a vain hope.
   In a musty locker room before the game, Coach Christy
divides the team into offensive and defensive alignments.
Hockey -- even by HNA standards -- is so fast-paced that
players need to be rotated on and off the ice every 90
seconds or so to keep fresh legs in the game. The coach,
apparently doubting my potential, assigns me to the last of
three forward lines, each with three players. There also are
three pairs of defensemen.
   As I skate out onto the ice wearing a blue and orange
Lords jersey with a lucky 7 on the back, I see spectators
have begun assembling for the game. Only four spectators, but
in a moment of pre-game jitters, I trip and fall over my
stick.
   The action begins. Skate blades flash up and down ice,
bodies thump against the boards -- the fencing on the
perimeter of the playing area -- and sticks crackle on pads
and the darting puck. Some Lords are graceful. Then there is
Bill McDermott, a 34-year-old hospital manager playing
offense. He winds up for a big slap shot -- one of hockey's
most dramatic moments. On the downstroke, however, Bill's
stick misses the puck entirely, spinning him in a
half-circle. "Hey, Bill, I could feel the breeze," one of the
Lords, Max Mintzer, yells from the bench.
   The Lords first score comes when Aram Dakarian, who
manages a supermarket meat department, makes a nifty pass to
Gary Poteshman. This time, stick and puck connect. The black
disk floats into the net, and the Lords hoist their sticks to
celebrate the team's first goal. Players sitting on the bench
lean over the boards and bang them with their sticks.
   The goal ties the score 1-1, and it is now time for our
third line to make its first appearance. That's me.
   As I climb nervously onto the ice, the coach grabs my
jersey and tells me to "hang back and try to get a feel for
the flow of the game. See how fast you can skate. . . ." I
detect some concern in his voice.
   From the bench, an HNA game doesn't look particularly
frenetic. But on the ice, it takes all my energy to keep up.
I am soon out of breath, the puck seems always to be headed
the other way. Toward the end of my shift, I have a brief
chance to shoot. But just before I let go, two Bandits
converge and hack at me with their sticks. I feel as though I
am caught in a threshing machine. As I struggle to stay on my
feet, the puck vanishes.
   Returning to the bench, I notice steam escaping my jersey
and coming out of the holes in my socks.
   My second turn on the ice is more eventful. After a
teammate passes me the puck, I maneuver around a Bandit
defenseman, glide toward the net and shoot. For a moment it
looks like the puck might actually get through, but the
goalie blocks the shot with his glove. "I was robbed," I
mutter to my plastic face shield.
   In a flash, the Bandits are back on the attack in our
zone. I try to tie up one of them in front of our goal just
as another Bandit winds up for a slap shot. While my opponent
and I are whacking at each other, the hard rubber puck
ricochets off the seat of my pants.
   The bench explodes. "Hey, Wall Street Journal. Great
defense," someone shouts.
   Penalties become a big problem for the Lords as the game
progresses, as we are forced to play short one man for
extended periods. That inspires a lecture from our coach on
the fine points of fouling the other team without getting
caught.
   Throughout the game, both benches shout encouragement to
their fellows doing battle on the rink. During one of my
rushes, I hear the Lords loudly shouting my name. Touched, I
tip my helmet to them, only to discover that they are just
trying to get me off the ice. I have played a minute past my
line change, thus keeping one of our stars from his turn at
play.
   After several scoring opportunities go awry in the third
period, some Lords are feeling frustrated. "We can't buy a
goal," our captain yells in despair. But the 1-1 deadlock is
finally broken when Bill McDermott redeems himself for his
earlier whiff. Accepting a pass from Frank Winterer, a
banker, Bill moves in toward the net and scores. He's a hero.
   In the closing minutes, with the Lords still ahead by one
goal, Coach Christy gets excited: "Trip them, hold them, jump
on them. Just don't let them score]"
   As it happens, we actually score again ourselves, and I am
credited with an assist on the final goal in our 3-1 victory.
   After the game, Coach Christy has high praise for my
performance. "Well," he says, "you didn't embarrass yourself
too badly."
doc\n900402-0008..title:
Out of His League:
   He Is No Gretzky,
   But Then Who Is?
   ---
   Our Man Plays the Left Wing
   And Gives Lords an Assist;
   A Deft Defensive Move
   ----
   By John Koten
   Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal

The shrinking role of profits is evident, as Mr. Hunt
says, in comparisons of profits and the gross national
product, the broadest measure of overall economic activity.
In the 1960s, amid the longest economic expansion in the
history of the U.S. business cycle, corporate profits,
adjusted for inventory gains or losses and for depreciation,
reached 11.7% of GNP. This percentage fell to a low of 6.9%
near the trough of the subsequent 1969-70 recession. Since
then, as the chart below shows, the pattern has been for the
percentages to be lower at both expansionary high points and
recessionary low points.
                                                                                                       

   The latest reading, for last year's fourth quarter, is
5.3%. This is appreciably below the high for this expansion
of 7.3%, set in the second quarter of 1984, but it remains
well above the low for the 1981-82 recession of 4.5%. It also
is substantially higher than where Mr. Hunt, given the
pattern of progressively falling levels of both the high and
low readings, places the new "recessionary range." For him to
become concerned about profits dragging the economy into a
recession in coming months, he says, they would have to fall
to about 3% of GNP.
   Mr. Hunt shares the view of most forecasters that such a
decline will not occur. The consensus is that economic growth
will slowly accelerate as the year goes along, and in the
process profits will increase. For instance, 51 forecasters
polled by Blue Chip Economic Indicators of Sedona, Ariz.,
estimate on average that the economy will grow 2.3% annually
in the year's last half and profits will rise as well.
   In the last three months of 1989, pretax profits continued
a decline that began early last year. But the rate of decline
slowed markedly to 0.5% from 7.1% in the previous quarter.
And, on an after-tax basis, profits edged up in the quarter,
reversing a yearlong slide.
   Profits, it should be noted, tend to lead the economy's
ups and downs. The government, in fact, continues to classify
them as a leading economic indicator, normally rising or
falling several months before such broader gauges as
employment and industrial production follow suit. Mr. Hunt
agrees that profits still tend to lead the economy, but he
adds that nowadays "the economy clearly can manage to keep
expanding through the sort of profit decline that once would
have signaled a recession."
   One reason, he says, is that service businesses, which
tend to operate on slimmer profit margins, now play a larger
economic role. More importantly, the huge increase in
corporate indebtedness in recent years has served to reduce
profits. Corporations' net interest costs -- interest expense
less interest income -- reached a record 52% of profits in
last year's fourth quarter, up from less than 2% a
quarter-century ago.
                                                                                                       

   The interest that corporations pay on their bonds and
other borrowings, of course, may be deducted from their
profits, reducing taxes. The upshot is that many firms that
have undergone leveraged restructuring now show weak profits
or lose money, and yet remain in operation, providing jobs
that help sustain overall economic activity.
                                                                                                       

   The economy, to be sure, cannot continue indefinitely to
expand if profits keep dropping. Many analysts, in fact,
attribute much of the economy's recent sluggishness to the
profit decline of the past year and its impact on corporate
hiring and spending. And some forecasters remain convinced
the profit decline signals a recession is near.
   Perhaps so. But with a reduced role for profits, that
possibility may prove less likely than in the past.

doc\n900402-0012..content:
Analysts said profits for each ton of steel shipped will
range from $15 to $25 in the first quarter. That result
compares with $26 in the fourth quarter of 1989 and $39 a ton
in last year's robust first quarter.
   Among major steelmakers, USX Corp. appears to have fared
the best in the latest period, partly reflecting the
company's labor cost advantages. Analysts predict that the
Pittsburgh steel and energy concern should earn between 55
and 60 cents a share compared with a $1.09 a year ago.
   Most major steelmakers, except for USX, had higher
first-quarter labor costs stemming from new labor pacts
negotiated last year. Bethlehem Steel Corp., the first major
steelmaker to sign a contract last year, is expected to earn
about 15 cents a share in the latest quarter compared with 78
cents last year.
   The automotive sector, which consumes about 23% of U.S.
mills' output, was weak through much of the quarter, picking
up toward the end. As a result, steelmakers, such as National
Steel Corp., that are largely dependent on auto-related
customers are expected to fare badly. Analysts expect
National Steel, a Pittsburgh joint venture owned by National
Intergroup Inc. and NKK Corp. of Japan, to earn about $12 a
ton.
   The outlook for the rest of the year is mixed. Mr.
Jacobson said he initially thought the steel industry would
suffer at least two quarterly losses in 1990. But now he
expects a quicker upturn as prices begin to climb. "I think
we're pretty much out of the woods," he said.
   Other analysts, though, expect the lackluster first
quarter to persist through 1990. "Look for anemic profits in
1990" said Peter Marcus, an analyst with PaineWebber Inc. He
cited flat shipments, higher labor costs and continuing price
weakness as reasons for the slump.
   Some analysts, such as John Tumazos of Donaldson, Lufkin &
Jenrette, believe softness in automotive and construction
markets will extend to the previously strong capital goods
market. "Historically, after the consumer segment is weak for
two to four quarters, the capital goods market begins to
ease," he said.
   Steelmakers suffered from lower prices in the first
quarter, a trend that began in the second half of 1989. Mr.
Tumazos said average first-quarter prices fell to $491 a ton
from $503 a ton in the fourth quarter. "I don't think the
public will be aware of how deep the discounts were until
they see the first-quarter results," he said.
   Price declines have been most severe for commodity-type
products such as hot rolled sheet. Mr. Marcus noted that the
base spot price for that product fell to about $310 a ton
from $325 in the fourth quarter and $400 a ton last spring.
Moreover, world spot prices for even high quality products
like cold rolled sheet recently fell an additional $40 a ton,
partly as a result of overproduction, Mr. Marcus said.
   Those steelmakers with more long-term contracts and less
exposure to the spot market, such as Armco Inc., Parsippany,
N.J., and Chicago-based Inland Steel Industries Inc., are
less vulnerable to spot price discounting.
   Also hurting first-quarter results, noted analyst
Christopher Plummer of WEFA Group, were lower operating
rates. Those rates were about 82% in the first quarter
compared with the year-earlier quarter's 90%. As a result,
fixed interest and labor costs were spread over fewer tons of
steel shipped. "It's enough of a drop to have a significant
impact on earnings," he said.
   Still, shipments held up relatively well in the quarter
despite the lackluster economy. One reason was the low level
of imports. First-quarter shipments should total about 20
million tons, slightly higher than the fourth quarter but
lower than the 1989 first quarter's 21.9 million tons. The
strength in shipments is expected to continue in the second
quarter as buyers rebuild inventories, a move that should
also relieve some pressure on pricing.

Built in 1972, the structure is an award-winning example
of suspension-bridge architecture. Its 10-story
reflective-glass office tower seems to hang between two
pillars on a block-sized downtown plaza. The bank's vault is
underground.
   Initially, the bank's staff recommended temporarily
relocating while asbestos was removed and other renovations
and repairs were made. But officials abandoned that plan
after determining that the 550,000-square-foot structure
couldn't be easily expanded to meet growing space
requirements.
   Bank officials now are seeking to build, buy or lease a
larger facility. A spokesman said the current building could
be sold, leased or perhaps traded. "We're open to all
options," he said.

On the Toronto Stock Exchange Canron Class A shares last
traded Friday before a trading halt at C$11.50, unchanged. In
Toronto, Ivaco Class A shares closed at C$10.25, down 25
Canadian cents.
   Paul Ivanier, president and chief executive officer of
Ivaco, said funding for the acquisition would come from the
combined resources of Ivaco and Canron.
   Both Ivaco and Canron have been struggling lately. Each
posted a loss for 1989 after extraordinary items and losses
from discontinued operations.

The company recommended a final dividend of 12.5 pence a
share, which would boost the total payout for the year 19% to
21.5 pence from 18 pence.
   Pearson said the results represented "the best-ever
profits for the group," with record earnings for its
publications, the Financial Times, the Economist and Les
Echos, the publishers Addison-Wesley and Longman, financial
services interests and Royal Doulton china unit.
   Profit attributable to shareholders was boosted by an
extraordinary profit of #104.4 million, mostly from shedding
assets. Net income rose 57% to #276.2 million from the
year-earlier #175.7 million, which included an extraordinary
gain of #48.8 million.
